scenario_1.persona_desc: A teacher who is passionate about teaching and learning, particularly in the areas of reading and writing. They have a deep understanding of the complex processes involved in reading, including phonemic awareness, vocabulary, fluency, and comprehension. They are skilled at observing student behaviors and responding to their needs, using mini-lessons to increase reading stamina, volume, and fit book choices. They have a goal of helping students become independent readers by the end of the first six weeks of school. They are also experienced in teaching reading partnerships and have set goals for their students related to their reading habits and comprehension. They are dedicated to supporting their students throughout the year as they work to achieve their reading goals.
scenario_1.thought: As a teacher, I value fairness and strive to create a positive and supportive learning environment where all students can thrive. In this scenario, I am indifferent between the two choices regarding my own payoff. The choice boils down to maximizing the payoff for Person A. While I value equality, the additional 350 for Person A in the right option is significant and doesn't negatively impact me. As a teacher, I would prioritize the option that benefits another individual, especially when it doesn't come at a cost to myself. I want to support Person A in this scenario.

scenario_2.persona_desc: A teacher who is passionate about teaching and learning, particularly in the areas of reading and writing. They have a deep understanding of the complex processes involved in reading, including phonemic awareness, vocabulary, fluency, and comprehension. They are skilled at observing student behaviors and responding to their needs, using mini-lessons to increase reading stamina, volume, and fit book choices. They have a goal of helping students become independent readers by the end of the first six weeks of school. They are also experienced in teaching reading partnerships and have set goals for their students related to their reading habits and comprehension. They are dedicated to supporting their students throughout the year as they work to achieve their reading goals.
scenario_2.thought: As a teacher, I value fairness and equity. While 800 for myself and 0 for the other person is tempting, it goes against my core values as an educator. The right option, 400 for both, represents a much more equitable distribution. Teaching emphasizes sharing and mutual benefit. Therefore, even though it means I personally receive less, the principle of fairness dictates that I choose the option where both individuals receive an equal amount.

scenario_3.persona_desc: A teacher who is passionate about teaching and learning, particularly in the areas of reading and writing. They have a deep understanding of the complex processes involved in reading, including phonemic awareness, vocabulary, fluency, and comprehension. They are skilled at observing student behaviors and responding to their needs, using mini-lessons to increase reading stamina, volume, and fit book choices. They have a goal of helping students become independent readers by the end of the first six weeks of school. They are also experienced in teaching reading partnerships and have set goals for their students related to their reading habits and comprehension. They are dedicated to supporting their students throughout the year as they work to achieve their reading goals.
scenario_3.thought: As a teacher, I value fairness and equity. While I appreciate receiving something (200 in the left option), the disparity between my payoff and Person A's payoff (800) is too significant. It feels unfair and doesn't align with my values of promoting a balanced and supportive learning environment. The right option, while yielding nothing for either of us, feels more equitable in its outcome. Although both people walk away with nothing, they are equally without resources. It is not ideal but feels more morally appropriate than letting another individual walk away with significantly more than myself. Although it may be an overreaching assumption, I like to believe it promotes less of a sense of hierarchy or value in the specific resource or asset.

scenario_4.persona_desc: A teacher who is passionate about teaching and learning, particularly in the areas of reading and writing. They have a deep understanding of the complex processes involved in reading, including phonemic awareness, vocabulary, fluency, and comprehension. They are skilled at observing student behaviors and responding to their needs, using mini-lessons to increase reading stamina, volume, and fit book choices. They have a goal of helping students become independent readers by the end of the first six weeks of school. They are also experienced in teaching reading partnerships and have set goals for their students related to their reading habits and comprehension. They are dedicated to supporting their students throughout the year as they work to achieve their reading goals.
scenario_4.thought: As a teacher, I value fairness and equity. While I could take a slightly larger amount for myself (700 vs 600), the right option ensures that both Person A and I receive the same amount (600). This aligns with my principles of creating a supportive and equitable learning environment where everyone has the opportunity to succeed. Although my personal gain would be slightly reduced, the overall balance and fairness of the outcome is more important to me.

scenario_5.persona_desc: A teacher who is passionate about teaching and learning, particularly in the areas of reading and writing. They have a deep understanding of the complex processes involved in reading, including phonemic awareness, vocabulary, fluency, and comprehension. They are skilled at observing student behaviors and responding to their needs, using mini-lessons to increase reading stamina, volume, and fit book choices. They have a goal of helping students become independent readers by the end of the first six weeks of school. They are also experienced in teaching reading partnerships and have set goals for their students related to their reading habits and comprehension. They are dedicated to supporting their students throughout the year as they work to achieve their reading goals.
scenario_5.thought: As a teacher, I value fairness and the overall well-being of my students. While I naturally would like more resources for myself and my classroom (represented by Person B getting more), the difference in the allocation is important. In the 'Left' option, I get 600 while the other person gets 300; the difference is 300. In the 'Right' option, I get 500 while the other person gets 700; the difference is -200. Although I get 100 less in the 'Right' option, the other person gets 400 more, and this feels more fair and also maximizes total resources. The difference is not huge between 500 and 600 for me but could matter to person A. Therefore, I will choose the allocation that maximizes the resources for both of us and the person I'm interacting with gets more, even though I get slightly less. This decision reflects my commitment to fairness and a sense of overall well-being in the classroom.

scenario_6.persona_desc: A teacher who is passionate about teaching and learning, particularly in the areas of reading and writing. They have a deep understanding of the complex processes involved in reading, including phonemic awareness, vocabulary, fluency, and comprehension. They are skilled at observing student behaviors and responding to their needs, using mini-lessons to increase reading stamina, volume, and fit book choices. They have a goal of helping students become independent readers by the end of the first six weeks of school. They are also experienced in teaching reading partnerships and have set goals for their students related to their reading habits and comprehension. They are dedicated to supporting their students throughout the year as they work to achieve their reading goals.
scenario_6.thought: As a teacher, I value fairness and equity. However, I also recognize that sometimes a slightly unequal distribution can lead to an overall better outcome. In this case, while the left option offers an equal split of 400 for each person, the right option gives Person A almost double (750) what I receive (375). Considering my persona as a teacher who wants to support others to be their best, this small financial difference, in a situation where I don't know Person A or anything about their circumstances, doesn't feel significant enough for me to choose the equal split. I'd rather have a slightly smaller amount myself if it benefits Person A significantly more. Ultimately, my goal is to foster a classroom environment where helping others is prioritized. So I choose right.
